content: How can I help you today?

I think I just need to know where to even start. There's so much going on right now—problems with my son, my wife, work. It's hard to focus on any one thing without feeling like I'm drowning in everything else.

It sounds like there’s a lot happening in your life right now, all pulling you in different directions. You might be feeling overwhelmed, and that makes it difficult to figure out where to start or what to prioritize. How have you been holding up through all of this?
Honestly, not well. I feel like everything is falling apart, and no matter what I do, I can't seem to make anything better. It's exhausting, and I just don't know how to keep going like this.

Thank you for sharing how you’re feeling. It takes courage to acknowledge that things are tough right now. It sounds exhausting trying to deal with everything at once and still feeling stuck. What’s been helping you push through during times like this, even when it feels so heavy?

I’m not sure anything is helping, to be honest. I feel like I’m just going through the motions, trying to get through each day. It’s hard to feel like I can lean on anyone because I don’t want to burden my wife even more, and I don't know what else to do.

That sounds really heavy—to feel like you’re carrying so much on your own and unsure where to turn for support. It’s understandable that you wouldn’t want to add to your wife’s stress, but it can also be tough to navigate everything alone. What does leaning on someone for support look like for you when you do let someone in?

I honestly don’t even know anymore. I guess just having someone who gets it, who can listen without judging or trying to fix everything, would help. But it’s hard to open up—I’m not used to doing that.

It sounds like you're craving understanding and connection, but opening up feels unfamiliar or challenging for you. That can be a big step, especially when you’re not used to letting others in. What do you think might make it feel safer or more doable to share with someone when you’re ready?

I’m not sure—it just feels really hard to trust that anyone can really understand what I’m going through. Maybe if I felt like they really cared without trying to fix me, it’d be easier. But I don’t know where to start or how to even put everything into words.

It’s understandable to feel hesitant about opening up, especially when it’s hard to find the right words and you wonder if anyone can truly understand. You’ve already started putting it into words here, sharing what’s weighing on you—so you’re doing more than you think. What do you think sharing your experiences could mean for you, if it felt right and safe to do so?

It might help me feel less alone in all of this. I’m carrying a lot, and if someone could really understand, maybe it wouldn’t feel so heavy. But it’s hard to believe that saying anything will actually change things.

It sounds like part of you really wants to lighten the load and feel less alone, even if another part wonders whether it would make a difference. It’s such a difficult place to be, wanting relief but unsure how or if it will come. What would it mean for you if even one part of this weight felt a little less heavy?

I guess it would mean I could finally breathe, even just a little. Maybe if one part got better, it’d be easier to manage everything else. It just feels like everything’s tangled together, and I don’t know how to untangle it.

Taking that first breath—letting a small part of this weight lift—sounds like it could bring a sense of relief and make the rest a bit more manageable. It’s understandable to feel like everything’s so connected that it’s hard to know where to start. What feels most tangled or heavy to you right now?

Right now, it’s definitely my son. His behavior issues are just nonstop, and my wife and I can’t agree on what to do about it. It’s affecting our marriage, and I feel like I’m failing as both a parent and a partner. That’s probably the biggest weight on me.

That sounds incredibly challenging—feeling the strain of your son's behavior, the disagreements with your wife, and the pressure on your roles as a parent and a partner all at once. It's clear how deeply you care about your family and want things to get better. What do you wish could improve when it comes to your relationship with your son or with your wife?

I just wish I knew how to help my son without feeling like I'm constantly failing him. I want to feel like my wife and I are on the same page, working together, instead of arguing over what to do. It feels like everything I do is wrong, and I just want to be a good dad and a good husband.

It’s clear how deeply you want to support your son and strengthen your partnership with your wife. Feeling like you’re falling short despite your best efforts must be incredibly frustrating and weighing heavily on you. What’s something you’ve done as a dad or husband that you feel proud of, even during these tough times?

I honestly can’t think of anything right now. Everything feels like it’s falling apart, so it’s hard to see the good in what I’ve done. Maybe I’ve kept trying, even when it feels hopeless, but I’m not even sure if that’s enough.

Continuing to try—especially when it feels hopeless—is a powerful thing. It shows how deeply committed you are to your family, even in the hardest moments. Holding on to that determination says a lot about your strength. What could acknowledging the effort you've put in help you see differently about yourself or your situation?
